Experiment A: Vesper was being led down a passage towards the back of the house. Le Chiffre observed his assistant’s work attentively. “Search him.” barked Le Chiffre. Le Chiffre was standing in the doorway of a room on the right. Like lightning the Corsican slammed himself back against the wall of the passage and, as Bond’s foot whistled past his hip, he very quickly, but somehow delicately, shot out his left hand, caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc, and twisted it sharply. With a backward kick which connected with the thin man’s shins and brought a whistle of pain from him, Bond hurled himself down the passage after her. Then, as if reading Bond’s thoughts, he crossed the room and said, “Come my dear friend. As he crashed to the ground, Bond rolled agilely and, with a motion that he hoped went unnoticed, moved his fountain pen deeper into his breast pocket, he righted himself with minimal damage. Bond suddenly decided. Let’s not waste time.” He twisted Bond around brusquely in search of other weaponry. The two gunmen dragged Bond to his feet. He crooked a finger at Bond in a silent, spidery summons. While the thin man kept his gun trained on Bond’s unquiet chest, the Corsican roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. His plan was to do as much damage as possible to the two gunmen and be able to exchange a few hurried words with the girl.

Experiment B:
Bond was unharmed, but he was trapped. Three large men leapt through, guns drawn. He caught Bond’s shoe at the top of its arc and twisted it sharply. They roughly stripped Bond’s revolver out of its shoulder holster. He noticed that he had a white thread on his lapel, and removed it. The largest of the men was Le Chiffre, Bond’s recently vanquished opponent. He crossed the room to Bond, and patted him down once again. As Bond turned to leave the room, the door burst in toward him. “Search him.” barked Le Chiffre. Bond looked in the mirror of his hotel room to make certain that his black tie was centered in his collar. Filled with confidence after defeating Le Chiffre, Bond had extended an invitation to Vesper to dine with him in the hotel restaurant. The two gunmen carefully searched Bond. “Let’s not waste time.”
Bond felt puny and impotent. He smiled broadly, and flipped the comb well out of Bond’s reach. Unfortunately, the second gunman had accurately judged the rest of Bond’s motion. Le Chiffre pulled out Bond’s pocket comb and ran his finger down its teeth. She had cheerfully accepted. Bond smiled at the elegant figure he presented. As the three men approached him, Bond suddenly whirled around and caught one of the gunmen squarely in the stomach with a well-placed shove of his heel.
